frameDefinitions: This frame describes the Impression which a Figure, which can be a person, an organization, or an object, leaves with an Audience.
An Agent acts in such a way as to give the incorrect impression to observers that a particular State_of_affairs holds.
A phenomenon, the Indicator, exists as an indication of another phenomenon, the Indicated.
An Agent behaves as if they were a particular individual or type of Simulated_entity with the intent of misleading observers of their behavior.
This frame contains nouns that refer to sensations in different modalities.
An Entity persists in a stable situation called a State
frameExamples: He had an extremely fragile self - <t><fex name='Impression'>image</fex></t>
Jordan <t>feigned</t> a love of jazz music to get her phone number .
This is a <t>sign</t> of things to come.
The belfast bank robbers <t>posed</t> as police.
The huge sand dunes, perpetually changing, make for a surreal <t>sight</t>.
listRoleDefinitions: The entity (a person, organization, product, or event) for which the <fen>Audience</fen> has an <fen>Impression</fen>.
A person or group of people who have an <fen>Impression</fen> of a <fen>Figure</fen>.
A generalized conception of a <fen>Figure</fen> presented to or shared by an <fen>Audience</fen>.
The <fen>Agent</fen> is the person who acts in a misleading way to create the impression that a <fen>State_of_affairs</fen> holds.
This is the entity which is copied. With verbs it is frequently expressed as an NP Object: Pat <t>falsified</t> <fex name='Original'>the papers</fex>.
The Copy produced by the Creator most commonly occurs as the External Argument of a predicative use of an adjective or noun target: <fex name='Copy'>The painting</fex> is a <t>fake</t>.
The <fen>State_of_affairs</fen> is a an event, a state, or a property that the <fen>Agent</fen> wants others to believe have occurred or hold.
The <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Agent</fen> feigns something.
The place in which the <fen>Agent</fen> feigns something.
The phenomenon that signifies the <fen>Indicated</fen>.
The phenomenon that is signified by the <fen>Indicator</fen>.
The <fen>Agent</fen> is the person who acts in a misleading way to create the impression that they are a particular individual or type of <fen>Simulated_entity</fen>.
The type or individual that the <fen>Agent</fen> gives the impression of being.
The time at which the <fen>Agent</fen> impersonates the <fen>Simulated_entity</fen>.
The location where the <fen>Agent</fen> gives the impression that they are the <fen>Simulated_entity</fen>.
This role is only expressed with certain nouns in this frame, and then only with the help of a support verb, such as <ment>have</ment>:

This is the entity or phenomenon which gives rise to the sensation. In cases of veridical sensation, this role is not typically distinguished from <fen>Percept</fen>. Most of the phrases that express this role can be paraphrased as <ment>from</ment>-phrases, e.g.

The role <fen>Percept</fen> is used for phrases that express the characteristic property of a sensation. Typically this characteristic property is described with reference to the entity or phenomenon that produces the sensation---that  is why this role can be difficult to distinguish from Source. It is possible for Source and Percept to be expressed separately, however:

This role is assigned to phrases expressing the body part in which a sensation is located. Since touch is the least localized of sense modalities, words relating to haptic sensations are the ones most likely to occur with this FE:
This role is the perceptual background against which the Phenomenon is experienced by the Perceiver.
The <fen>Time</fen> when the sensation is perceived.
Concrete or abstract entity
State of an Entity.
listRoleExamples: A year after <fex>Audrey Seiler</fex> faked her own kidnapping while at college in Wisconsin, her lawyer says she's getting help and paying restitution.
A college student who staged <fex>her own disappearance</fex> last month will try to reach a plea agreement and avoid trial on charges she obstructed officers.
He was unable to display any <fex>sign</fex> of pain.
We now exhibt the same symptoms <fex>of the same disease</fex>.
<fex>I</fex> have a tingling sensation in my hands.
The smell <fex>of the garlic</fex> made me hungry.
This herb gives off a smell <fex>of garlic</fex>.
I have a tingling feeling <fex>in my hands</fex>.

sourceCandidateSpans.text: the middle of the nineteenth century
